2025 SEP 16 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- Investigators publish new report on remote sensing. According to news originating from Harbin, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The release of CO [ [2] ] from human activities and forest fires constitutes the two primary and most significant contributors to the global warming process."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation Project; Science And Technology Basic Resources Survey of Ministry of Science And Technology.
Our news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Harbin Normal University: "Identifying distinct types of CO [ [2] ] emission sources is crucial for developing targeted emission reduction measures tailored to varying intensities. In this study, an integrated methodology framework has been proposed to identify abnormal carbon release zones, clarify human-induced versus natural emissions, and quantify their respective contributions. To achieve this, Greenhouse Gases Observing Satellite XCO [ [2] ] , NO [ [2] ] , and CO data were analyzed across the globe using cluster-based segmentation and vector autoregressive modeling. Specifically, primary regions of anthropogenic and forest fire CO [ [2] ] emissions were identified based on these datasets. Furthermore, influencing factors affecting anthropogenic CO [ [2] ] emissions in China were quantified. Notably, human activities or forest fire regions were effectively distinguished from each other by K-means clustering of XCO [ [2] ] (anomaly) alongside NO [ [2] ] and CO data."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "In China, anthropogenic CO [ [2] ] emission patterns exhibit significant regional variability due to factors such as the output value of secondary and tertiary industries, residential energy consumption, and motor vehicle ownership. This study offers substantial insights into identifying distinct types of carbon emission sources while providing a foundation for developing targeted emission reduction strategies based on their varying intensities."
For more information on this research see: Satellite-Based Differentiation of Anthropogenic and Forest Fire CO [ [2] ] Emission Regions. IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing, 2025,18():20851-20860. The publisher for IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing is IEEE.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1109/JSTARS.2025.3595540.
Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Mingdong You, Department of Geographical Sciences, Harbin Normal University, Harbin, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Shuying Zang, Li Sun, Yusheng Shi.

Last Monday afternoon, the Office of Disaster Risk Management of Cusco became aware of the occurrence of a forest fire in Pacaymayo Bajo, at Km. 96 of the railway, in the buffer zone of the world wonder, Machu Picchu.


Due to the time of day and strong winds, the fire could not be contained by personnel working in the area, and personnel had to leave early Tuesday morning.
It was learned that Sernanp will intervene with a total of 25 people who will travel from Piscacucho, Qoriwayrachina, Chachabamba, Machu Picchu Pueblo and Cultura Cusco will have 15 people who will travel from Piscacucho.
The company PeruRail has coordinated with the company to provide facilities to the forest firefighters who will travel to the site of the forest fire, who will be equipped with the corresponding equipment.
According to a last report, so far no deaths or health effects have been reported. As for the loss of natural coverage, it is in the process of evaluation, which will continue throughout the day.
On the subject, Miguel Oscco, director of the Regional Emergency Operations Center of the Regional Government of Cusco, said that the fire is located five kilometers in a straight line from the Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu.
"We have satellite monitoring in which different hot spots are identified, one of them in Machu Picchu. We hope it can be extinguished and liquidated as soon as possible. There is no risk for Machu Picchu or for visitors, but whenever we talk about this area there is always alert and concern. The important thing now is that the brigadistas can control the fire as soon as possible," he said.

The forest fire in the Cotacachi-Cayapas Reserve has been active since Monday, August 18 and, as of today, Friday, August 22, has consumed more than 1,485 hectares of forest.


Fire in Cotacachi-Cayapas Reserve consumes more than 1,485 hectares of forest
The National Secretariat of Risk Management reported this Friday, August 22, on the current situation of the fire in the Cotacachi-Cayapas Reserve.
It was reported that, due to weather conditions, there are three new hot spots located on the right flank of the reserve.
As of today, four days after the fire started, 1,485 hectares of moorland vegetation have been consumed.
At the moment, the BRIF of the Quito Fire Department is active , working in coordination with the Cotacachi and Urcuquí firefighters to control the flames. Firefighters from Otavalo and Antonio Ante have also joined in.
Unified efforts to fight the fire
In addition, park rangers from Cotacachi Cayapas National Park, Sangay, Illinizas, Llanganates, and El Boliche Natural Reserves are participating in the firefighting operations in the mountains.
The Ministry of Environment, the cantonal GAD with the Rupay Forest Fire Alert Plan, and community members from Piñán, Cahuasquí, Buenos Aires and other communities also participated in the fire control tasks.
The Quito Fire Department supported with drone overflights to evaluate the fire. As well as the GAD cantonal de Cotacachi that collects information.
The firefighters and other people trying to control the fire are living a hard day in the mountain due to the location and the slope of the affected mountain.

Forest fire near Machu Picchu keeps alert active in CuscoThe fire, reported last Monday afternoon, is advancing through a wild area inside the historic sanctuary. So far, an estimated 8 hectares of flora and fauna have been affected.

Marcela Marañón, the Peruvian who conquered the 7 wonders of the world in a wheelchair

Luis Alvarez
Alert. Last Monday afternoon, in the sector of Pacaymayo Bajo, at kilometer 96 of the railway line to Machu Picchu, province of Urubamba, in Cusco, a forest fire of considerable proportions was reported.


The director of the Regional Emergency Operations Center (Coer), Miguel Oscco, explained that the fire occurred in an area of difficult access.
"It is a fairly rugged area with slopes and lush vegetation that make the work difficult. However, accredited SERNANP brigades have already been mobilized and we are coordinating with personnel from the municipality and the province of La Convención to reinforce the work if necessary," he said.
The official added that during the afternoon, SERNANP personnel, supported by six reforestation specialists, began containment work, but had to suspend the work at nightfall. "For this morning, the intervention of 40 brigades is planned, 25 from SERNANP and 15 from the Decentralized Direction of Culture, who will move from different points such as Piscacucho, Chachabamba and Machu Picchu Pueblo," he said.
On the other hand, the municipality of Machu Picchu is coordinating the logistics and transportation of the teams, including hydration, food and specialized equipment. In addition, PeruRail set up special stops at kilometer 96 to facilitate the access of combatants to the affected area.
No damage to patrimony
Oscco clarified that, despite the proximity of the fire to the Inca citadel, no damage to houses, people or cultural heritage has been reported. However, the fire affected 8 hectares of flora and fauna.
"We are worried that the fire could grow, it is approximately 5 kilometers away, in a straight line from the Inca llaqta and affect cultural zones, but so far there is no risk for the railway line or for the archaeological sites nearby", he said.
For its part, the COER indicated that the evaluation of damages in the natural cover will be updated in the next hours. At the time of going to press, the Decentralized Directorate of Culture of Cusco had not commented on the matter.

urn:contentItem:6GNR-CKY3-RWT1-C22C-00000-00Sernanp brigades and Cusco DDC maintain monitoring actions after controlling forest fire in the Machupicchu SH2025-09-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisSernanp brigades and Cusco DDC maintain monitoring actions after controlling forest fire in the Machupicchu SH

Although the fire has been controlled, the staff continues to be deployed due to the presence of smoke at critical points to avoid possible reactivation.The forest fire reported since Monday, September 1 in the Pacaymayo Bajo sector, within the Historical Sanctuary of Machupicchu, is controlled thanks to the work articulated between the National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (Sernanp), an agency assigned to the Ministry of Environment, the Deconcentrated Directorate of Culture Cusco and the District Municipality of Machupicchu.

Despite having controlled the forest fire, the field staff maintains permanent monitoring actions due to the presence of smoke at inaccessible points, which could generate reactivations. The deployed brigades perform air monitoring through drones to identify hot spots and smoke, mainly in the areas of Pacaymayo Bajo, Pampacahua and surrounding areas.

Joint operation and logistics support

Today, a Sernanp gang performs monitoring and liquidation work, while a team of the Culture DDC evaluates the state of cultural heritage in the area, working in a coordinated and preventive way to prevent the fire from rekindling.

The operation has support from the District Municipality of Machupicchu, which provides food, hydration and logistical support to the brigades, as well as with the support of Perurail, which facilitates the transfer of personnel and equipment towards the critical points.

In addition, monitoring drones are used to assess the behavior of smoke and detect possible reactivation risks.

No effects have been reported in homes, crops or tourist activities.

The drizzle registered at dawn of September 3 contributed to the control of the main spotlights of the fire.

urn:contentItem:6GNB-4G83-RTX7-G1F5-00000-00Forest fire in Machu Picchu: tourists and inhabited areas are not likely to be affected by the fire2025-09-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisForest fire in Machu Picchu: tourists and inhabited areas are not likely to be affected by the fire


The forest fire that is registered in the archaeological park of Machu Picchu, Urubamba province of Cusco, has already consumed thirteen hectares of bushes and native trees on the third consecutive day, confirmed the Office of Disaster Risk Management and Security (OGRDS) Machu Picchu.


According to the latest report, the forest fire is advancing in the "Pacaymayo bajo" sector, kilometer 96.500 of the Ollantaytambo-Machu Picchu railroad, right bank of the Vilcanota River.
Fortunately, the movement of the flames does not threaten inhabited areas and the passage of tourists to the Inca citadel of Machu Picchu, which is 15 kilometers away.
However, brigades of forest firefighters from the Ministry of Culture, Sernanp, municipality of Machu Picchu and the national police resumed this morning the work of control and liquidation of the forest fire from two flanks, right and left. On the right side it would be approaching the Panpaqawa monument and on the left side it would be heading towards a ravine.
Dangerous zone
In the last meeting of the operations command it was analyzed that the active fire, in both flanks, registers uneven areas "the fire is in the ravines, being difficult to attend on the part of the combatants", they refer in the report. However, constant monitoring is being carried out from the command post installed in Pampaqawa, where priority is given to ensure that the fire does not reach the monument.
Finally, it is reported that logistics, breakfast, lunch, hydration and others are provided to the combatants, as well as the transfer of the brigades by train.
The OGRDS, through the Machu Picchu District Emergency Operations Center (COED), will register the emergency in the SINPAD platform. This code will include the Damage Assessment and Needs Analysis (EDAN) of the emergency and the actions to be taken by the entities.
It was preliminarily reported that there are 13 hectares devastated, there is no damage to life and health of people, no houses, the fire does not affect the passage of trains to Machu Picchu Pueblo, therefore it does not affect tourists and residents.

A forest fire broke out yesterday afternoon, Friday, September 5, in the district of Cotahuasi, province of La Unión, and as of today, Saturday, it is still active after more than 12 hours of uninterrupted spread.


According to preliminary information, the fire has consumed approximately 100 hectares of vegetation cover, mainly natural grasses. No damage to life or health of people has been reported, as confirmed by the District Municipality of Cotahuasi through its Disaster Risk Management Office.
According to the entity, the fire started around 18:30 hours in the sectors of Huambo, Pitahuasi and Quillunsa. Despite the efforts deployed, the flames have not yet been completely controlled. In addition, local media questioned the lack of presence of authorities to contain the fire, as well as the loss of queñuas.
Brigades from the serenazgo are participating in the work, along with local residents, who have been working to prevent the fire from spreading. However, the magnitude of the fire and the conditions of the terrain make the work difficult.
According to the district municipality, control and extinguishing work continues with the participation of serenazgo brigades and local residents, who are working to prevent the fire from spreading. However, there is fear that it could spread due to the presence of winds at midday. Likewise, the municipal authority regretted that there is no support from the Regional Government of Arequipa.

The forest fire that started on Friday, September 5 in the district of Cotahuasi, province of La Unión (Arequipa), is still out of control in some high areas despite the efforts of brigadistas and authorities.


So far, the flames have consumed some 200 hectares of natural cover between pastures and bushes, according to the latest official report.

urn:contentItem:6GJS-G0W3-RRVG-820D-00000-00An electrical failure in a photovoltaic plant triggered the forest fire in Casas de Don Pedro.2025-08-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisAn electrical failure in a photovoltaic plant triggered the forest fire in Casas de Don Pedro.


The forest fire which last June devastated around 800 hectares in the municipality of Casas de Don Pedro had its origin inside a photovoltaic plant, as confirmed by the investigation of the Nature Protection Service (SEPRONA) of the Civil Guard.


Investigations determined that the fire started in a solar panel tracking box which overheated. The fire spread thanks to the high temperatures and also, allegedly, to the lack of proper application of the Extremadura Forest Fire Prevention Plan (PREIFEX) at the facility, according to Canal Extremadura.
The fire spread rapidly through the area of Las Trescientas and Navalallegua, threatening isolated houses and livestock facilities. The Junta de Extremadura declared Level 1 of danger and deployed a large device with aerial and terrestrial means, natural environment agents and members of the Guardia Civil.
Thanks to the intervention, the fire was under control in a few hours, although the damage affected crops, holm oak groves and scrubland. A dozen neighbors filed complaints for the damage caused.
In view of the evidence gathered, the SEPRONA has instructed the person in charge of the photovoltaic power plant, a neighbor of Casas de Don Pedro, as a person under investigation for an alleged crime of forest fire. The case has already been referred to the Court of Instruction of Herrera del Duque.

urn:contentItem:6GPK-Y623-RS92-21RS-00000-00Arequipa: Forest fire cannot be controlled for three days, in Cotahuasi2025-09-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisArequipa: Forest fire cannot be controlled for three days, in Cotahuasi


The forest fire registered since last Friday afternoon in the district of Cotahuasi, province of La Unión, is still active and affecting more than 350 hectares of vegetation cover. In spite of the efforts of local authorities and residents, the fire is spreading rapidly through sectors of dry grass, intensified by strong winds at peak hours.


The intervention brigades are facing serious difficulties due to the fact that the fire's outbreaks are located in wild and inaccessible areas, which has delayed control efforts for the past three days.
No damage to human life or health has been reported, as the Quillunsa community members themselves had to organize themselves to prevent the flames from reaching the area.
However, the situation is not improving in the Huambo sector, where conditions are not conducive to extinguishing the fire, and because it is a private property used for cattle, it is being affected on a large scale.
In this regard, the provincial mayor of La Union, Alfonso Chipana Nuñuri, reported that yesterday a group of 40 people were deployed, including villagers, local officials, Sernanp, among others, but as the area was inaccessible, they returned to return.
"At times it increases where there are larger bushes and grass, at other times it goes down, but there is no longer a risk to the population. It affects flora and fauna. Besides, we cannot risk the 40 people, the area is very risky, as far as we can, it is done", expressed the municipal authority.
He added that if the fire is not controlled in the parts, they expect it to extinguish itself, as has happened with 99.9% of the fires reported in the province so far this year. "Unfortunately, we are going to have to wait, if it moves further upwards, it will be for it to extinguish itself", he said.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-5DF3-S4Y1-94YF-00000-00A resident of A Coruña is arrested as responsible for a forest fire while carrying out agricultural work2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisA resident of A Coruña is arrested as responsible for a forest fire while carrying out agricultural work


The Nature Protection Service (Seprona) of the town of Corcubión, in A Coruña, has arrested a man accused of being the alleged perpetrator of a forest fire in the area.


As they have detailed in a statement, the man would be responsible for starting the flames of the fire that occurred on August 6 in the town of Prudenza, in the municipality of Zas. The fire was reproduced on the 9th of the same month due to weather conditions in the area.
On trialThe man would have carried out agricultural tasks with machinery that lacked spark retention elements.
The Civil Guard then initiated an investigation to clarify the causes of the fire and to identify the perpetrator or perpetrators.
After analyzing the information gathered, the agents were able to find out that they had been carrying out agricultural work with machinery on the farm where the investigators had located the starting point of the fire.
Once they had located the machinery that carried out the work, they inspected it and found that it lacked the spark retention elements stipulated in the legislation for the prevention and defense against forest fires.
Once the identity of the alleged perpetrator was known, the Civil Guard arrested the man, accused of a crime of forest fire due to gross negligence. The detainee has been placed at the disposal of the Court of Instruction of Corcubion.

urn:contentItem:6GP7-TS83-RV5X-226T-00000-00Tribhuvan University Researchers Describe New Findings in Forestry (Forest fire dynamics in Nepal: Regional trends and socio-ecological drivers)2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisLIFE SCIENCES - FORESTRYTribhuvan University Researchers Describe New Findings in Forestry (Forest fire dynamics in Nepal: Regional trends and socio-ecological drivers)


2025 SEP 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Life Science Daily -- Fresh data on forestry are presented in a new report. According to news reporting from Kathmandu, Nepal, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Forest fires pose a significant threat to global ecosystems and communities. In Nepal, the country's diverse vegetation, climates, and socioeconomic settings contribute to unique regional fire dynamics, which are often underrepresented in national forest fire analyses."


Funders for this research include Tribhuvan University.
The news editors obtained a quote from the research from Tribhuvan University: "This study investigates fire trends, key drivers, and public perceptions of management strategies across Nepal's four major physiographic regions: the Terai, Chure, Middle Mountains, and High Mountains. We employed remote sensing data, questionnaire surveys (n = 337), and statistical modelling to assess regional fire dynamics and evaluate management approaches. We found that over the past two decades, fire incidents and burned areas have increased significantly in the Chure and Middle Mountains. Broad-leaf deciduous forests in lower regions and needle-leaf forests in higher regions were the most significant contributors. While topographical factors played a major role in most regions, they had minimal influence in the Chure. In the High Mountains, anthropogenic factors-such as proximity to roads and agricultural land cover-were strongly negatively correlated with burned area. Pre-monsoon precipitation consistently showed a significant negative relationship with fire occurrence across all regions, whereas pre-monsoon temperature had no discernible impact. Survey responses highlight strong community support for awareness programs and training, and a widespread belief in the importance of local institutions in fire management. However, labor-intensive fire prevention practices, such as creating fire lines and collecting leaf litter, were less preferred."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "To mitigate future fire risks, we recommend strengthening community involvement, expanding fire management training, and increasing economic incentives linked to forest resources. These findings offer valuable insights into Nepal's fire regimes and support evidence-based forest fire management strategies."
For more information on this research see: Forest fire dynamics in Nepal: Regional trends and socio-ecological drivers. Trees, Forests and People, 2025,21():100942. The publisher for Trees, Forests and People is Elsevier.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tfp.2025.100942.
Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Khagendra Prasad Joshi, Central Department of Hydrology and Meteorology, Tribhuvan University, Kathmandu, Nepal. Additional authors for this research include Susma Giri, Dipesh Kuinkel, Sajesh Kuikel, Rohini Devkota, Dhiraj Pradhananga, Suresh Marahatta, Binod Pokharel.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-9923-RSCJ-F1GF-00000-00Man arrested in Llanes for allegedly setting a forest fire on August 212025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisMan arrested in Llanes for allegedly setting a forest fire on August 21


The Civil Guard has arrested a 55-year-old resident of the council of Llanes, as the alleged perpetrator of a crime of forest fire without propagation, which occurred last August 21 on a track located between the sites of La Conjita and Las Lagunas, in the vicinity of Celorio.


As reported by the Guardia Civil, the events took place around 19.20 hours, when an agent, who was off duty on a hiking route, came across a vehicle whose driver warned him that the road had no exit.
The officer decided to continue on foot along the path, locating a few meters ahead a fire outbreak on the edge of the road, on the edge of a meadow. Thanks to his rapid intervention, he managed to smother the flames with his own means, preventing their spread in an area of high vegetation, with abundant brush, ferns and brambles over one meter high, as well as eucalyptus, chestnut and oak trees.
The action took place in a context of extreme fire risk, with the Forest Fire Emergency Plan of the Principality of Asturias (INFOPA) activated in emergency phase level 2, and with all the regional, state and UME resources deployed in the fight against other active fires in Degaña, Genestoso, Caunedo, Bezanes, Camarmeña, Arcenorio and Pachalina.
Once the fire was extinguished, the agent reported the facts to a patrol of Public Safety, providing the description of the vehicle with which he had crossed minutes before. This made it possible to quickly locate and identify the driver.
At the same time, the Nature Protection Team (Seprona) of Gijón prepared a technical report which concluded that the fire had been intentionally provoked by the direct approach of a flame.
The arrest of the suspect took place this Thursday morning. The proceedings have been sent to the Court of First Instance and Instruction of Llanes.

urn:contentItem:6GS9-PSV3-RSF4-H45P-00000-00Timbio firefighters and rescue team battled hard to control huge forest fire2025-09-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisTimbio firefighters and rescue team battled hard to control huge forest fire


Firefighters from the municipality of Timbío, Cauca, and members of the rescue group, GER, worked for more than five hours to counteract a forest fire that broke out in the sector of Puerto Llave, located in the limits of this town and El Tambo.


According to one of the first reports of this situation, the peasant communities of this part of the southwest of Cauca alerted how the gigantic flames threatened to destroy homes and crops on the night of Tuesday, September 16.
"With the support of this rescue group GER, our units arrived in time to the area to fight the flames little by little, always taking safety measures not to expose themselves too much to the strong radiation that was formed by this fire, possibly caused by the strong summer that we live in this part of southern Cauca", expressed the firefighters of Timbío.
Also, and at the time of attending this situation, the firefighters and rescuers had the support of the community, whose members joined the fight to protect their homes, animals and crops, an aspect that was key to avoid possible tragedies.
"The farmers in the area were key when attending to this emergency, which left as a balance around 50 hectares of vegetation reduced to ashes, of course, environmental damage is confirmed because many wild animals died, but well, fortunately our intervention prevented seven houses in the sector from ending up not affected by the flames, thus protecting these families, as well as their crops," added the firefighters.
In view of this situation, and seeking that both these communities and other inhabitants of southern Cauca help to prevent fires, firefighters reported that it is important to avoid burning or bonfires when taking walks in these places, not to throw cigarette butts on the lawn, or leave glass or other items that may end up generating a magnifying glass effect.
"If you are surprised by the fire, you should always remain calm and not spread unfounded rumors, as happened in this case, where people sent verified information to our units, thus facilitating the work and of course call the official emergency lines to follow the instructions of the authorities.
If there is a need to evacuate, remember to turn down the electricity and gas switches, take with you the essentials (documentation, money and medicines) and go to where the first responders in the area indicate the services to follow the recommended evacuation routes", the first responders specified.

urn:contentItem:6GKM-BNY3-RSC5-G39C-00000-00Israel develops AI to increase accuracy in forest fire prediction2025-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisIsrael develops AI to increase accuracy in forest fire prediction


Jerusalem - Researchers at Tel Aviv University have developed an artificial intelligence (AI)-based method that improves forest fire prediction by adapting it to the specific conditions of each country or region. The study was published in Nature's journal npj Natural Hazards.


Extreme wildfires, increasingly frequent due to climate change, release large amounts of greenhouse gases, threaten communities and infrastructure, and severely damage ecosystems.
Inaccuracy in current methodology
Until now, most meteorological risk indices, designed in countries such as Australia, Canada and the United States, lose accuracy when applied in other areas.
The new method corrects this problem by adjusting the models to local factors such as climate, vegetation, land use and ignition sources.
The accuracy of the predictions increased from 70% to 86%. First, the scientists calibrated the Canadian index - considered the most reliable - using a genetic algorithm, raising its accuracy to 80%.
Then, they developed a country-specific AI model, converted into a simple, field-applicable decision tree.
This breakthrough could improve early warnings, optimize resource allocation and reduce damage, providing a basis for future wildfire prevention systems in an increasingly hotter world.

2025 SEP 23 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in Machine Learning. According to news originating from West Bengal, India, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "Forest fires, a growing global threat, have increased in intensity and frequency over recent decades due to climate change and human activities. These fires may destroy biodiversity and cause environmental degradation, habitat loss, and exacerbate human-animal conflicts."


Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Vidyasagar University, "Certain cultural practices in countries like India further intensify the problem, especially from March to May, when dry deciduous forests accumulate combustible biomass. Despite several challenges, the early prediction of forest fires can significantly mitigate their impacts. However, most previous studies have overlooked the dynamic nature of climatic factors in their predictive models. This research aims to fill this gap by producing a 5-day early prediction map, that incorporates climatic conditions from the preceding 6 days, as well as vegetation health and topographic factors. In this study, three different machine learning algorithms, i.e., random forest, extreme gradient boost, and support vector machine, were evaluated to identify the most effective model for early fire prediction. The models were trained using nearly 2000 ground-based fire observations collected between 2017 and 2022, and included sixteen driving factors encompassing climatic, topographic, anthropogenic, and forest health parameters. Our findings highlight the key factors influencing fire occurrences, with all models achieving over 80% accuracy in 5-day early predictions, and Random Forest demonstrating the highest overall performance. Critical determinants for fire susceptibility included elevation, temperature, and relative humidity. The practical utility of the model was further validated through three distinct case studies during March 2022, a peak period for forest fire occurrences. These case studies achieved an area under the curve (AUC) value exceeding 85% for 5-day early predictions, confirming the effectiveness of the model."
According to the news editors, the research concluded: "The resulting 5-day early susceptibility maps provide valuable insights for timely warnings, enabling better prevention, resource allocation and optimizing management efficiency to reduce environmental, ecological, and economic losses."
This research has been peer-reviewed.

urn:contentItem:6GM2-96F3-RSY7-J4W3-00000-00A voracious forest fire affected Las Heras, Mendoza2025-08-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisA voracious forest fire affected Las Heras, Mendoza


A forest fire broke out in Las Heras, province of Mendoza, this Thursday afternoon.
According to TN, the fire originated very close to the Industrial Park of Las Heras, in the north of the city, about three kilometers from Mendoza's El Plumerillo International Airport.


The flames reached more than five meters high in an uncultivated field full of dry grasslands. In addition, the fire spread rapidly due to the wind, which was blowing in a northerly direction, endangering several nearby houses.

However, several fire departments arrived and managed to contain the fire. Volunteer Firefighters from Las Heras, together with Firefighters from Godoy Cruz, personnel from the Central Fire Station, Police Firefighters and the support of the Civil Defense of the province and of Las Heras worked at the place.
Although the circumstances in which the fire originated have not yet been determined, the director of Civil Defense of the province, Daniel Burrieza, assured that it was intentional. "They have set fire. There is no cause that could have caused the fire, it was a person," he said.

He also gave details about the situation. "In this same property, there are several fire outbreaks, so we are trying to contain them to prevent it from reaching the Industrial Park," Burrieza explained minutes after 3:00 pm. He also confirmed that no injuries were reported.
The area where the fire broke out registered a temperature of 22°, although the flames reached dry grasslands and were spread by the wind. No rain was forecast for today. However, Fernando Confessore, meteorologist of TN, explained that there is no extreme condition that increases the risk of fire, but that it is probably an "oversight, a fire caused by man's hand", because the weather conditions are not conducive to a fire outbreak. Meanwhile, rains were forecast for Saturday and Sunday.

urn:contentItem:6GPT-XJ03-SGRP-90FD-00000-00Forest fire in Arequipa: Concern over reactivation of fire in La Unión2025-09-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisForest fire in Arequipa: Concern over reactivation of fire in La Unión


After 5 days of having registered the forest fire in the district of Cotahuasi, province of La Union, yesterday it could be controlled to 98% due to the work of the same settlers, officials of the National Service of Natural Areas Protected by the State (Sernanp), local authorities, set of brigades, and COER of the Regional Government of Arequipa.


However, the provincial mayor of La Unión, Alfonso Chipana Nuñuri, admitted that there is a risk that the fire could restart in dry and difficult to access areas. To this is added that the winds of the afternoon, being intense, contribute to its reactivation.
"It has been controlled and there are people waiting for it not to rise. There is a fear that it could be reactivated because the terrain is immersed (in Huambo), the area is pasture land and all that has been burned", he mentioned. In addition, he assured that there are brigades to avoid the expansion of the fire. "They separate the burned area so that it does not reignite. We hope that it will be controlled and that the winds will not favor it", he added.
Due to the fire reported since 18:30 hours last Friday and a late reaction of the regional authority, the fire devastated approximately 500 hectares of natural pastures, affecting the flora and fauna of part of the Cotahuasi Sub-basin Landscape Reserve.
No damage to the lives or health of the population was reported because the Quillunsa community members organized together with other neighboring towns to stop the flames.
Regarding the equipment and resources destined for the emergency, the mayor said that these were already in the municipality's warehouse, so the guidance and supervision of the regional entity was lacking, in addition to other support measures. He clarified that this situation is repeated every year, so they expect better prevention actions this season.
Likewise, the COER manager, José Luis Barrezueta, said that the fire would have been caused by the burning of residues from agricultural fields that were not controlled by some residents.

A large number of crops, full production, were affected.The Regional Government of Lima, through the Regional Management of Natural Resources and Environmental Management, quickly mobilized a team of specialists from the Civil Defense Office towards the Huarochirano district of San Damian, with the purpose of articulating immediate actions in front of a forest fire that was recorded in the area.

The incident generated serious damage to the agricultural and livestock. Hectares of potato and corn crops, main sources of sustenance of peasant families, were reduced to ashes. Likewise, smoke and fire put the risk of parenting animals such as sheep and cows, vital resources for the communal economy. Fortunately there are no human damage.

As part of the intervention, non -perishable foods were delivered to the affected families, as well as the provision of tools to the gangs of the sector, in order to strengthen the work of control and mitigation of the damages caused by the emergency.

In that sense, the neighbors are urged to remain calm and collaborate with the preventive measures adopted by the specialized brigades, while resources and support are managed to meet the most urgent needs of those affected.

With this deployment, regional management reaffirms its commitment to protect the life, safety and subsistence means of vulnerable families of Huarochiri, reinforcing articulated work against natural disasters.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VP93-RSMG-X229-00000-00Forest fire in Holbox, Yucatan, did not originate on PMD property, according to satellite imagery2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisForest fire in Holbox, Yucatan, did not originate on PMD property, according to satellite imagery


The forest fire that consumed a little more than 700 hectares of vegetation on the Isla Grande of Holbox, Quintana Roo, did not originate on property belonging to the Peninsula Maya Developments (PMD) company, according to Sentinel-2 satellite images from the European Space Agency and Landsat from NASA/USGS.


Records from August 23 and 24 show that the fire started in the eastern zone of the Yum Balam Flora and Fauna Protection Area, more than half a kilometer from the company's land. However, these properties were the most affected by the spread of the fire.
The fire spread rapidly due to the prevailing winds and the density of the vegetation.
After six days of continuous work, the fire was completely extinguished thanks to the intervention of brigadistas and personnel from the Secretariat of the Navy (Semar), the Secretariat of National Defense (Sedena), the National Guard, the National Forestry Commission (Conafor), the National Commission of Protected Natural Areas (Conanp), as well as the Civil Protection of Quintana Roo and the municipality of Lázaro Cárdenas, with the support of a tanker helicopter provided by the Government of Yucatán.
The environmental impact includes the loss of shrubs, mangroves and lowland jungle, which affected habitats of various species of wildlife.
Conafor's brigadistas are conducting tours in the area to prevent reactivations, while environmental authorities are working on a restoration plan.
Peninsula Maya Developments filed formal complaints to investigate the origin of the fire and to determine who is responsible.
Biologist Rubén Presuel, member of the Yum Balam reserve's advisory council, said:
"To determine the cause of the fire, specialized experts, who are available at Conafor and Conanp, should be called in. It could even have been caused by lightning, since the fire occurred during the rainy season."

urn:contentItem:6GR1-WSH3-RRKC-X40T-00000-00Higuera forest fire caused by a truck has been stabilized, but the fire is still closed.2025-09-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisHiguera forest fire caused by a truck has been stabilized, but the fire is still closed.


The Forest Fire Fighting Service of Andalusia, Plan Infoca, has stabilized the fire in the place La Dehesilla de Higuera de la Sierra (Huelva), which originated from the fire of a truck but remains cut in both directions the N-433 road.


As reported by the Directorate General of Traffic on its website, consulted by Europa Press, the incident occurred at kilometer 73 of the N-433, so alternative detours were enabled by the A-479 and the A-461. Thus, although the fire has been stabilized the cut of both lanes is maintained.
For its part, the Infoca has reported that the fire has been stabilized at 13.10 hours on Thursday, since the area have moved to quell the fire six groups of forest firefighters, an extinguishing technician, three technical operations, an environmental agent, four fire trucks and two bulldozers, a medical unit and a unit of Meteorology and Analysis.
Also, to work by air have come two cargo planes on the ground, two light amphibious, a coordination plane, as well as a light helicopter and a semi-heavy helicopter.
From the Provincial Fire Consortium have explained that the fire originated around 3.12 hours and that the truck is not of goods, but the fire spread rapidly moving towards an industrial estate and has approached the limits with the municipality of Zufre.
Therefore, two trucks and three firefighters from the Consortium's Aracena fire station were sent to the scene, and the Jabugo fire station was quickly joined by three trucks and three firefighters, although the latter have already been withdrawn.

urn:contentItem:6GR7-VP53-RSMG-X1K8-00000-00Santa Cruz declares forest fire emergency2025-09-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisSanta Cruz declares forest fire emergency


The Secretary of Citizen Security of Santa Cruz, Luis Fernando Suárez, announced this Friday, September 12, 2025 that the department has been declared in emergency due to forest fires. This measure was made official through Departmental Decree 505, with the objective of facing the effects of climate variation that threaten life, people's integrity and food security.


Suarez reported that the fires have caused significant damage in the productive sector and in several communities. Currently, there are 7 active fire outbreaks. In areas such as El Encanto, San Matías, San José, Ipiá and Santa Clara in Ascensión de Guarayos, forest firefighters are working hard to put out the fire.
In addition, there are 4 other fires that are under surveillance. These fires are located in Río Blanco and Río Negro in Concepción, Palmito in Rivero Torres and an additional fire also in Concepción. The emergency declaration will be in effect from September 11 until December 31, 2025. During this time, the necessary resources will be coordinated to control the fires.
Activation of the COED
The Departmental Emergency Operations Committee (COED) has been activated to evaluate the needs of the most affected municipalities and to ensure the necessary logistics to face the situation. This morning, an Airbus 350 B3E helicopter, which arrived from Chile, joined the fire containment efforts in San Ignacio de Velasco, reinforcing the fire response.
The post Santa Cruz declares emergency due to forest fires first appeared on Periódico La Patria.

urn:contentItem:6GHS-DW03-RTM0-84P3-00000-00Studies from Eotvos Lorand University Update Current Data on Sustainable Forests (Assessing Collaborative Management Practices for Sustainable Forest Fire Governance In Indonesia)2025-08-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisSUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH - SUSTAINABLE FORESTSStudies from Eotvos Lorand University Update Current Data on Sustainable Forests (Assessing Collaborative Management Practices for Sustainable Forest Fire Governance In Indonesia)


2025 AUG 18 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Economics Daily Report -- Researchers detail new data in Sustainability Research - Sustainable Forests. According to news reporting from Budapest, Hungary, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Our research examines the dynamics of policy implementation in forest fire management and how local governments in Indonesia can successfully implement these policies. There are two main issues: first, the extent to which forest fire management practices are collaborative, which we assess by examining whether government implementation has focused on developing integrated forest fire management policies represented through collaborative networks."


The news correspondents obtained a quote from the research from Eotvos Lorand University, "Second, we consider whether and how governments and other competing stakeholders move from conflict to collaboration to enable policy implementation. This research explores whether and how collaborative management can provide a foundation for successful forest fire management, particularly in Riau Province, Sumatra, Indonesia, an area that has experienced significant forest fires and expansion of plantations and oil palm industries. Data were collected through in-depth interviews and observations. We revealed a lack of coordination among local, central, and other stakeholders, which might result in policy 'tyranny'. In order to effectively reduce the number of fires, the government needs to empower those responsible for fire prevention through law and policy."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "However, because forest fire management is inherently top-down and often excludes lower levels of bureaucracy, collaborative management remains challenging."
For more information on this research see: Assessing Collaborative Management Practices for Sustainable Forest Fire Governance In Indonesia. Forests, 2025;16(7):1072. Forests can be contacted at: Mdpi, St Alban-Anlage 66, Ch-4052 Basel, Switzerland.

Copa Peru teams dispute pass to the final phase in the middle of a forest fire: unexpected phenomenon spread during the matchIn the province of Concepción, Atlético Sumar Motors and Centro Estudiantil de Cajas faced each other in the middle of an irrational setting for the Copa Perú. The incident stole the attention of social networks.

Emilio Carranza
The Peru Cup 2025 has once again left us with an anecdotal event. Macho soccer, as it is often called in our country, gives us surreal moments from time to time. This case is no exception. In the province of Concepción, Junín region, the match between Atlético Sumar Motors and Centro Estudiantil de Cajas was being played. Both teams were competing for a place in the final, but beyond that, what was really striking was that a forest fire broke out during the match.


The unexpected incident occurred at the Richard Muller Bosseler Municipal Stadium. While the clubs were playing for the third phase of the departmental stage, the transmission of the match focused on the precise moment when the fire began to develop on the heights of the hill.
Forest fire 'invade' match in the Peru Cup 2025
The match was taking place normally on the field. Surprisingly, one of the people in charge of the live transmission commented, when the scoreboard was still not moving: "You can also see a forest fire at the top of the hill, here in the province of Concepción".
Despite the environmental incident, the game was played without interruption. Atletico Sumar Motors took the victory and secured the last place in the next stage of the Copa Peru. Along with them, Unión Juventud Pomacocha from Yali-La Oroya and Atlético Chanchamayo also qualified as representatives of the Junín region.
In this way, Atletico Sumar Motors defined its opponent for the round of 16: it will face Centro Deportivo ANBA Peru, a team representing the province of Puno. The championship is at a crucial stage, with a total of 64 teams in contention.

This Tuesday a forest fire has been registered and remains active at kilometer 96 of the railway line that connects Ollantaytambo with Aguas Calientes, in the province of Urubamba, Cusco region.


Authorities indicated that the fire mainly affects the high areas of the sector, while in the lower areas it has been possible to control the emergency by brigadistas.

The incident has been affecting the border between the districts of Machu Picchu and Ollantaytambo, about 15 kilometers from the Historic Sanctuary of Machu Picchu. For the time being, it does not represent an immediate threat to the archeological centers or the flow of tourists.
According to the director of the regional government of Cusco, Miguel Oscco, the fire would have been caused by an agricultural practice known as "roseo", which consists of burning vegetation to expand farmland.
The dryness of the soil and the lack of rainfall would have facilitated the spread of the flames. In addition, the intense winds have complicated the work of the brigadiers in the higher areas, who had to suspend their intervention for the time being due to the danger involved.
Train traffic between Ollantaytambo and Machu Picchu Picchu has not been affected, and tourist activities are developing normally in the district of Machu Picchu Pueblo.
However, authorities have reiterated the need to remain vigilant in case of possible changes in wind direction.

The Junta de Andalucía is confident that the forest fire declared on Thursday night in the place of Las Cubillas, in Lubrín (Almería), can be stabilized throughout the afternoon this Saturday, after the operation has had to face a complicated night by the wind, which prevented close the perimeter of the fire.


The delegate of the Andalusian Government in Almeria, Aránzazu Martín, explained to the media that during the early hours of the morning the troops of the Plan Infoca tried to perimeter the area, but the wind, "strong and changing", forced to rethink the work. "With all caution, I hope we can declare this fire stabilized during the afternoon," he said in statements from the Advanced Command Post.
Martin has detailed that the device has been reinforced throughout the morning with numerous aerial means, which are added to the terrestrial, with the aim of attacking both the main front and the reactivations that occur at different points.
The delegate stressed that so far it has not been necessary to carry out new evictions of population, beyond those carried out preventively in the early hours of Friday morning in districts of Bédar and Lubrín, whose residents have already returned to their homes.
Nor have there been cuts in main roads, although in some secondary roads in the affected area.
In his speech, Martin thanked the work of more than 180 troops who are part of the device working on the fire and has appealed to the "caution" of the public while the extinguishing tasks are prolonged.
The Infoca Plan maintains its efforts on the western flank, in the area of El Chive, which is the most active, while the rest of the perimeter is contained and cold.
The work is taking place in a steep terrain, covered with dense scrub, where it is not possible to use heavy machinery and in which manual labor and technical fire techniques are used. From the Emergency Agency of Andalusia has been recalled that the evolution of the fire is conditioned by the gusts of wind and the complex terrain of the area.
The 112 telephone has managed more than 300 alerts since the declaration of the fire, which mobilized from the first moment to Civil Guard, Local Police, Firefighters, the National Police Unit Attached, the Emergency Group of Andalusia (GREA) and 061, in addition to the operational Infoca.

urn:contentItem:6H57-37W3-RT20-619D-00000-00Brazilian environmentalist gets funded by DiCaprio after false forest fire accusation by Bolsonaro2025-11-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisBUSINESS NEWSLIFESTYLEINTERNATIONAL NEWSENTERTAINMENT NEWSBrazilian environmentalist gets funded by DiCaprio after false forest fire accusation by BolsonaroMAURICIO SAVARESEAssociated PressBELEM, Brazil

BELEM, Brazil — Being falsely accused of setting fire in the Amazon with funds from an Oscar-winning actor eventually became a blessing in disguise for Caetano Scannavino, the coordinator of a nonprofit organization in the heart of the rainforest.

Brazil's then President Jair Bolsonaro falsely claimed in November 2019 that actor Leonardo DiCaprio had funded nonprofit groups that he alleged were partly responsible for setting the fires. The accusation, though false, created risks for Scannavino and his work promoting sustainable development and citizens' rights in a region along the Tapajos River popular with tourists for its blend of rainforest and beaches.

Four of Scannavino's friends who volunteered as forest firefighters were jailed for two days and then prosecuted as alleged perpetrators of fires in the region, only to be cleared later. Police scrolled through documents of Scannavino’s Saúde e Alegria nonprofit for weeks. Scannavino received anonymous threats, and his car was set on fire.

DiCaprio takes notice

But Bolsonaro's comments helped DiCaprio take notice of Scannavino's work and decide to sponsor his work through Re:wild, a nonprofit conservation group that the actor helped found. Their partnership has already lasted five years, the Brazilian activist said.

“When the accusations emerged, DiCaprio came out to say he was not funding us, but added we deserved his support after he saw our work,” Scannavino told The Associated Press in a phone interview. “I've never been with him or spoken to him. But he gives us support, uses his social media to show what this partnership does.”

The 59-year-old Scannavino became the coordinator of Saude e Alegria, or Health and Happiness, in 1988 to promote integrated and sustainable community development in Para state, whose capital Belem will host the United Nations' Conference of the Parties, or COP30, next week. Scannavino arrived in Belem on Tuesday from Santarem, the city where the initiative is based, after a two-day boat ride that featured broadcasts with journalists, activists and climate experts.

Local products hub

The project started as a health care initiative, but it has since grown to work with rural communities to improve their quality of life and exercise of citizenship.

One project sponsored by DiCaprio's institute is the Forest Economy EcoCenter in Santarem, which serves as a hub for processing, storage and commercialization of products made by locals. Organizers said the facility enhances the economic viability of sustainable practices in the region.

The hub was opened a year ago, and is also supported by the governments of Brazil, Germany and Norway, all contributors of the Amazon Fund, a Brazilian initiative that pays for anti-deforestation and sustainable development efforts.

Scannavino said that the initiative cost about 5 million Brazilian reais ($938,000), mostly paid for by the Amazon Fund.

“Those first few days after Bolsonaro's accusation were terrible. People insulted us and our families on the streets, the firefighters had to leave. But then a surprising thing happened,” Scannavino said.

“Usually people get away from you if such a big target appears on your back. It was the opposite with us. Eventually the accusations went away, the firefighters were released, and people were curious about us — including DiCaprio,” he added.

‘Meet the moment’

In an Instagram post this week, DiCaprio said the world leaders gathering in Brazil must ensure that those defending nature have the resources they need. He said Re:wild is pledging more money to protecting forests.

“I urge leaders to unite and meet the moment,” he said. “Our future depends on it.”

The AP emailed Re:wild seeking further comment on its work with Scannavino and at COP30.

Scannavino, who left the Brazilian metropolis Sao Paulo for the Amazon more than 37 years ago, said that DiCaprio and other backers of his nonprofit also came in support because he chose to show Bolsonaro he was working with the support of local police and armed forces instead of trying to score political points.

The former president was recently sentenced to 27 years in prison for a coup attempt in 2023 after losing his reelection bid.

“Our critics are specialists in hatred, and since that incident we chose to be polite, provide evidence we worked with all stakeholders, everyone who mattered in the region. We refused to leave our local communities without due health care assistance just because of an absurd accusation,” Scannavino said.

Many awards and acknowledgments later, Scannavino is expected to meet with Re:wild officials and perhaps DiCaprio himself at COP30.

Scannavino said that he nearly met DiCaprio about 20 years ago while setting up for a photo exhibition in New York. He said that the team preparing the photo exhibition didn't recognize the actor under a cap and complained that he was getting in the way, so he left.

“Shortly later our producer raced to tell me that was Leonardo DiCaprio," Scannavino said. "I told her to run after him and get him back. She caught him on his bike a few blocks away. He thanked her, but had to leave.

"I hope that the next encounter is a very different one, so we can thank him duly,” he added.

“When the accusations emerged, DiCaprio came out to say he was not funding us, but added we deserved his support after he saw our work,” Scannavino told The Associated Press in a phone interview. “I've never been with him or spoken to him. One project sponsored by DiCaprio's institute is the Forest Economy EcoCenter in Santarem, which serves as a hub for processing, storage and commercialization of products made by locals. Organizers said the facility enhances the economic viability of sustainable practices in the region.

The hub was opened a year ago, and is also supported by the governments of Brazil, Germany and Norway, all contributors of the Amazon Fund, a Brazilian initiative that pays for anti-deforestation and sustainable development efforts.

Scannavino said that the initiative cost about 5 million Brazilian reais ($938,000), mostly paid for by the Amazon Fund.

urn:contentItem:6GN4-P583-S4JY-80CH-00000-00Immersive 'forest fire' experience will act as powerful call for woodland and wildlife protection2025-09-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisWHATS ONImmersive 'forest fire' experience will act as powerful call for woodland and wildlife protectionDaniel OwensContributor

Fermynwoods Contemporary Art is thrilled to announce the upcoming presentation of Tipping Point, a powerful new work by internationally renowned artist Luke Jerram.

Showcased in the largest ancient urban woodland in the UK, at the heart of Corby town centre this September as part of the 350th anniversary of the Great Fire of Northampton, Tipping Point uses immersive light, smoke, and sound to simulate the drama of a forest fire.

The installation features a bespoke soundtrack created by BAFTA and Ivor Novello award-winning composer Dan Jones, which includes the sounds of burning trees, whirring chainsaws, and fleeing animals, alongside ambient, melancholic music and moving global testimonies from individuals who have experienced wildfires.

The work will be unveiled from 8pm to 9:30pm on the evenings of 19th, 20th and 21st September.

As part of the project, visitors will have the opportunity to find information about local environmental action, including North Northants Council’s work on increasing tree canopy cover and habitat preservation.

Fermynwoods Director, James Steventon added, “As climate fires rage around the world, we are excited to bring this powerful artwork to the county, thinking globally as we act locally to change the perception of Corby from a toxic town of environmental harm to an environmental leader.”

Tipping Point is commissioned alongside Luke Jerram’s Gaia, a breathtaking seven-metre installation of planet Earth, suspended high above the auditorium in The Core at Corby Cube; plus, What’s Eating Our Reality, an intimate, immersive three-course meal by artist Maya Chowdhry that uses digital projection mapping to explore the journey our food takes from seed to table.

The Councilor of Presidency, Demographic Challenge, Equality and Tourism and Vice President of the Governing Council, Gimena Llamedo, has declared the return to the emergency phase in Situation 0, at 13.36 hours, today Saturday, August 30, of the Forest Fire Plan of the Principality of Asturias (INFOPA).


At the moment in Asturias there are two stabilized fires in Ibias and Genestoso (Cangas del Narcea), and three controlled fires in Tineo, Degaña and Somiedo. In the case of the Ibias fire this Saturday will continue the work of auctioning and liquidation, as reported by the Emergency Service of the Principality of Asturias in a press release. In it will work the Brif of Tineo, Firefighters of Asturias and a forestry company.
After finishing the firebreak works in Villarcebollín and from Cecos to Villarmayor, the heavy machinery will continue with the same in Piñeira and Andeo.
In Genestoso, Cangas del Narcea, the mowing tasks will continue to be carried out by the Fire Department of Asturias and a forestry company. The Advanced Command Post (PMA) will continue in San Antolín de Ibias.
Regarding the three controlled forest fires, the one in Tuña/Merillés (Tineo) is pending review by the Guardia de Medio Natural and is not smoking. The one in Valdeprado (Degaña) is not smoking at any point and is pending review by the Guardia de Medio Natural. Finally, the Caunedo/Gúa (Somiedo) is pending review by the Environmental Guard.

A forest fire caused by a Ukrainian drone attack near the town of Gelendzhik, in southern Russia, appears to be approaching one of Vladimir Putin's luxury residences in the area, independent media outlet IStories reported on Thursday.


The fire broke out on Thursday, regional authorities have reported, spreading across at least 14 hectares and reaching Tyomnaya Shchel, a picturesque valley by the Black Sea.
Earlier in the day, the Russian Defence Ministryreported that air defence systems had shot down 18 drones over the region and a further 22 over the adjacent Black Sea overnight.
IStories pointed out that Tyomnaya Shchel is a mere four kilometres from Cape Idokopas, where one of Putin's residences is located. According to an investigation by Alexey Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation (FBK), some 7,000 hectares surrounding "Putin's palace" belong to Russia's Federal Security Service. It remains unclear if the palace itself suffered damage as a result of the drone attack.
While the FBKsaid the palace and park ensemble was built for Putin on a site covering an area of 67.9 hectares near the village of Praskoveyevka, 20km from Gelendzhik, on the Black Sea coast, the Russian authorities have repeatedly denied that the property belongs to Putin.

Mexicali, Baja California - The forest fire in the San Pedro Martir mountain range, which started on August 11, has accumulated 1,667 hectares, informed the State Civil Protection Coordination.


The Santa Rosa zone is the one that accumulates the largest affected area, being of greater concern due to its extension and low level of control due to its dry soil and winds.
Photo: Courtesy.
According to the latest preliminary report from the National Forestry Commission (Conafor), these are the results of the affected areas:

La Encantada: 401 hectares affected; 100% control and 98% liquidation.

Tasajera 1: 16 hectares affected; 100% control and 85% liquidation.

Tasajera 2: 150 hectares affected; 70% control and 60% liquidation.


The greatest challenge is in Santa Rosa, where the fire has damaged some 1,100 hectares and has barely reached 30% control and 20% liquidation. In total, approximately 1,667 hectares in the Sierra San Pedro Mártir have been affected.
To contain the advance, brigades opened firebreaks, carried out sanitation work with chainsaws and cooled hot spots.
In addition, two aircrafts carried out 25 water discharges in the last 24 hours to reinforce the most active fronts.
Photo: Courtesy.
Federal and state brigades, armed forces, park rangers, personnel from the National Astronomical Observatory and volunteers are participating in the fight. More than 80 combatants are working on the ground and in the air to extinguish the fire.
Access to San Pedro Mártir National Park remains limited until further notice.

The forest fire that broke out on September 5 in the Huambo sector, Cotahuasi district (La Unión), in the Cotahuasi Sub-basin Landscape Reserve, was brought under control after four days of arduous work by local brigades, regional authorities and local residents.

According to the Regional Emergency Operations Center (COER) of Arequipa, the fire consumed about 500 hectares of natural pastures, with no human casualties or damage to the health of the inhabitants.
To deal with the emergency, the Regional Disaster Risk Management Office (GRGRD) deployed a cistern, 10 water backpacks and 900 tools, while Sernanp brigades reinforced the operation with chainsaws, fire extinguishers and fumigation pumps. In addition, drones were deployed to identify critical points where smoke was still lingering.
The manager of the GRGRD, José Luis Barrezueta, said that the fire was caused by uncontrolled agricultural burning, although he specified that there is not enough evidence to formalize charges.
"A containment line has been made where we are preventing the fire from spreading towards Cotahuasi. We have to be attentive because the weather conditions are not favorable, the wind is blowing too much, and another hot spot has just been activated. We have also coordinated with the municipality, where we have an advanced warehouse with materials, shovels, picks, wheelbarrows and also with the regional government that has delivered water tanks that we are using to bring water and mitigate the fire", said Barrezueta.
Communities such as Chaucavilva, Cachana and Quillunsa participated in the first line of response, as well as brigadistas from the Julio Gonzales Ruiz Institute, the National Police and personnel from the Salinas and Aguada Blanca Landscape Reserve.
The authorities warned that they will continue with permanent monitoring because the wind conditions in the area could rekindle the embers and generate new fire outbreaks.

urn:contentItem:6GKF-KYV3-RWGD-N319-00000-00Portuguese authorities arrest two young men on suspicion of causing Lousã forest fire2025-08-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisPortuguese authorities arrest two young men on suspicion of causing Lousã forest fire


The Portuguese Judicial Police (PJ) arrested two young men on Saturday for allegedly setting a forest fire in the region of Lousã last Monday, August 18. According to investigations, the suspects used a lighter to set fire directly to vegetation in a rural terrain close to inhabited areas and the forest area of the mountain range, at a time of maximum fire risk due to very high temperatures and very low humidity.


Inter-institutional collaboration and prevention of further damage
The investigation counted on the collaboration of the Working Group for the Reduction of Fires in Rural Areas of the Littoral Center, which integrates elements of the PJ, the National Republican Guard (GNR) and the Institute for the Conservation of Nature and Forests (ICNF). The rapid intervention of the Lousã Municipal Fire Department prevented the flames from spreading to a larger area of the mountain range, thus preventing a larger fire.
The detainees will be brought before the Coimbra Judicial Court for their first interrogation and the application of the corresponding measures. The affected vegetation consisted mainly of grasses and brambles in an area of medium density, where the fire was deliberately started by direct flame, according to evidence gathered by the authorities.

urn:contentItem:6GPD-0423-RTWF-73SS-00000-00The forest fire declared on Saturday in Urraúl Alto is under control.2025-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisThe forest fire declared on Saturday in Urraúl Alto is under control.


The Navarre Fire Service has brought under control this Monday morning the forest fire declared on Saturday afternoon in Urraúl Alto.
This was announced at a press conference at the headquarters of SOS Navarra by the Minister of Interior, Civil Service and Justice, Amparo Lopez, who stressed that the troops are still in the area finishing off the tasks on the affected terrain.


The councilor emphasized that the quick action was the key to prevent the situation from escalating in a potentially very dangerous fire, with high temperatures, strong winds, a complicated orography for the action of terrestrial means and in an area with a lot of fuel for the flames.
In total, as reported by the counselor, the area affected by the fire was 60.4 hectares, consisting of approximately twelve hectares of woodland (Scots pine), one hectare of agricultural land and the rest of shrub pastures.
Firefighters from the Sangüesa, Cordovilla, Navascués, Navascués, Burguete, Tafalla and Estella-Lizarra fire stations and volunteer firefighters from Aoiz have participated in the extinguishing work. Also, two bulldozers of the Environmental Guard and members of the Policía Foral and the Guardia Civil. In addition, volunteers from the Red Cross have participated by providing supplies to the troops on site.
With regard to the aerial resources, two helicopters of the Government of Navarra and two helicopters of the MITECO based in Noáin were initially involved. Subsequently, more resources were requested to MITECO, and two ground loader planes from Agoncillo (La Rioja), the forest brigade (BRIF) from Lubia (Soria) with another two helicopters, a medium helicopter from Plasencia del Monte (Huesca) and a coordinating plane from Zaragoza joined the fire extinction work, which worked in the area during Saturday and withdrew when the situation improved and their help was not needed on Sunday.
In the current situation, the INFONA Plan (Special Civil Protection Emergency Plan for Forest Fires in the Community of Navarra) has been de-escalated to Operational Situation 0, which keeps the plan active in the pre-emergency phase.
The plan was active in Operational Situation 1 since Sunday afternoon due to the favorable evolution of the fire and weather conditions, which have allowed to de-escalate the plan, but remains active because the risk of forest fires expected for the coming days is still very high in some parts of Navarra.
The plan was initially activated in Operational Situation 2 on Saturday, due to the forecast that the development of the fire could seriously affect forest assets, and the need to request resources from MITECO (Ministry for Ecological Transition and Demographic Challenge) to help with the extinction work.

urn:contentItem:6GRW-S873-RXN7-S2N2-00000-00Jujuy: a strong forest fire broke out on National Route 66 and there is a high temperature alert.2025-09-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:40:43ZLexisNexisJujuy: a strong forest fire broke out on National Route 66 and there is a high temperature alert.


A grassland fire of considerable magnitude broke out this Monday morning on the collector road of National Route 66, at a short distance from the access to the Alto Comedero neighborhood, in the province of Jujuy.
The flames spread rapidly over the terrain due to the weather conditions and the accumulated vegetation in the area, which led to the intervention of several fire departments and personnel from the Fire Management System.


The fire started after midday, although the specific causes have not yet been determined. The fire affected a large area of grasslands and caused concern due to its proximity to inhabited areas.
The rapid spread of the fire forced the emergency teams to mount an operation to contain its advance and prevent it from reaching nearby houses.
According to local media Todo Jujuy, the outbreaks spread rapidly as a result of several combined factors: a temperature above 30 degrees, moderate winds and a high load of dry plant material.
At the time the fire started, the National Meteorological Service (SMN) recorded a temperature of 30.4°C in San Salvador de Jujuy, with a relative humidity of 39%, placing the city among the ten warmest localities in the country at that time.
The forest fire danger alert was already in force throughout the province since early morning hours. The SMN had warned about favorable conditions for the generation of igneous outbreaks, especially in the Valles and Yungas regions, where the risk level was classified as high to extreme.
Until Monday afternoon, no confirmed victims or material damages were reported, although the containment work continued with intensity for several hours.
Emergency personnel remained on site performing cooling and monitoring tasks to prevent a possible reactivation of the outbreaks.
The extended forecast for San Salvador de Jujuy does not offer an encouraging outlook in the short term. According to the SMN, temperatures will remain high throughout the week, with maximum temperatures of 31°C on Thursday and 33°C on Friday, and a low probability of significant rainfall.
This climatic context, added to the state of the soil and vegetation, keeps the risk of new similar episodes active.
How to prevent forest fires
In the framework of the Forest Fire Prevention Day, the organization GreenpeaceArgentina disseminated a series of recommendations with the aim of reducing the risk of fires in natural environments.
According to the coordinator of the Forestry campaign, Hernán Giardini, "it is estimated that 95% of forest fires are started by human causes", so it is crucial to strengthen prevention and expand the response capacity at both provincial and national level.
Among the measures highlighted are:

Do not light fires outside authorized places.

Extinguish campfires thoroughly with plenty of water and earth.

Do not throw cigarette butts or lit matches.

Avoid the use of pyrotechnics and fireworks.

Do not burn garbage or pruning remains.

Keep the grounds clean of dry grass.

Immediately notify the authorities in case of detecting smoke or fire.

Do not park vehicles on dry grasslands.

Do not use tools that generate sparks in times of risk.


In this context, one of the places most affected by forest fires was Patagonia. During the 2024-2025 season, fires affected 31,722 hectares in the Andean Patagonian Forests, quadrupling the damaged area compared to the previous cycle. The most affected provinces were Neuquén, Río Negro and Chubut, with direct impacts on conservation areas, protected areas and local communities.
For Greenpeace, these data reflect the limits of the current prevention and combat system. The organization warned that the resources allocated to the National Fire Management Fund are insufficient and that it is necessary to advance in the eradication of exotic species such as pines, which increase the risk of fires and hinder the recovery of ecosystems.
The fire on Route 66, which caused the alert in Jujuy, is part of a national context of forest emergency, with increasingly frequent and intense phenomena. Although no structural damage or evacuations have been confirmed, the authorities continue working to mitigate the impact and prevent new outbreaks in the coming days.
